unnormalised: The curious case of the ever-expanding title is a phenomenon that’s been plaguing the Indian professional landscape for far too long. It's reached a point where a simple "Manager" just won't cut it anymore. We now have "Senior Vice President, Head of Strategic Synergies and Innovation," a title so long it barely fits on a business card, and frankly, makes you wonder if they actually *do* anything besides attend really long meetings.

unnormalised: Let's be honest, who among us hasn't encountered someone whose job title sounds like it was generated by an AI specifically programmed to maximize corporate jargon? You meet someone at a wedding and ask what they do, and they reply with a title that takes longer to recite than it takes to explain the entire plot of a Bollywood film. You're left nodding politely, pretending you understand that "Chief Visionary Officer of Digital Disruption" is anything other than "in charge of the office Wi-Fi."

unnormalised: And it's not just the C-suite folks. Even fresh grads are getting in on the action. My cousin, straight out of IIT Delhi, landed a job as a "Junior Associate, Emerging Technologies Evangelist." Evangelist! He’s selling code, not salvation! What happened to the good old days of just being an “Engineer”? Now, he claims he has to “architect strategic solutions for disruptive innovation” which, as far as I can tell, involves fixing printer jams.

unnormalised: This inflation of titles is, I suspect, a very Indian phenomenon. It’s a cultural thing. We love a bit of pomp and show. It's in our DNA. Why be a "Teacher" when you can be a "Distinguished Educator and Mentor"? Why be a "Doctor" when you can be "Dr. (Med), FRCS, Consultant Specialist in Advanced Cardiac Interventions"? More is more, as they say, especially when it comes to impressing Sharmaji's son at the Diwali party.

unnormalised: Ultimately, I think we all need to take a step back and ask ourselves: are these ludicrously long titles actually serving any purpose? Are we truly innovating, disrupting, and synergizing, or are we just adding syllables to our job descriptions to make ourselves feel better? Maybe, just maybe, it’s time we all embraced the beauty of simplicity. Perhaps "Engineer," "Manager," and "Professor" are good enough after all. Or maybe, I’m just a disgruntled "Senior Analyst of Existential Title Crisis Management," which, in reality, translates to “I write blog posts.”
